The impact of the development State practice applying the control and capabilities test remains to be seen. This benefit is also a downside. Quicker attribution can also lead to false positives. It is widely known within the cyber community that States can mask their true identity, and make it appear that the attack is originating in a separate State. The foregoing examples of State practice support the conclusion that imputed State responsibility for the unlawful cyber operations of non-State actors who are neither *de jure* nor *de facto* State organs is being assigned without rigid adherence to the “effective control” test. How A New Legal Regime Is Shaping Attribution In Cyberspace

## I. INTRODUCTION
Attribution in cyberspace is one of the most difficult questions facing policy makers, lawyers, and jurists. Indeed, the first question often asked in the wake of a cyber incident is “who did it?” The answer to this question is often critical when dealing with the application of international law because it will dictate the rights and responsibilities of States both from an offensive and defensive perspective. Without proper attribution, for example, a State’s responsive capabilities are limited. Making matters worse, attribution is difficult to establish factually. Non-State actors often mask their identity, and State actors often hide their true intentions. The degree to which the international rules governing State attribution apply in cyberspace is therefore a matter of great public importance.
It is widely accepted amongst States and scholars that the rules of international State responsibility generally apply in cyberspace. Those rules, reflective of the *lex generalis*, provide that the acts of a State’s *de jure* and *de facto* organs are generally attributable to the State.² The internationally wrongful acts of non-State actors (who are neither *de jure* nor *de facto* State organs) may also be imputed to the State if the non-State actors operate on the instructions of, or under the direction or control of the State.³ This general rule relative to non-State actors, commonly referred to as the “effective control”⁴ test, is widely recognized as the *lex generalis*
governing imputed State responsibility for the internationally wrongful acts of non-State actors. Accordingly, as the *lex generalis*, the rule does not vary “with the nature of the wrongful act in question” unless there is a “clearly expressed lex specialis.”⁵ The “effective control” test, as the *lex generalis*, therefore applies in cyberspace.⁶
This paper posits that a new *lex specialis* is, in fact, forming that, if risen to the level of customary international law, would supplant the *lex generalis* “effective control” test and allow for imputed State responsibility for the internationally wrongful cyber operations of non-State actors even in the absence of express direction or control. This new test, which this paper calls the “control and capabilities” test, would allow for the attribution of non-State actor cyber activity based on a multi-factored test, examining: (1) the relationship between the non-State actor and the State, if any; (2) the cyber methods used by the non-State actor and whether those methods are similar to the State; (3) the motivations of the two parties, if known; (4) the similarity in technology and/or code used by the two parties; (5) the technical capabilities of the two parties; and (6) geographic location. In other words, direction and control are

## II. ATTRIBUTION LEGAL FRAMEWORK
### A. Law of State Responsibility
The law of State responsibility is premised on two elements: (1) whether the act or omission in question is internationally wrongful; and (2) whether the act or omission in question is attributable to the State.8 This paper only focuses on the latter as a normative question.9
### B. Attribution Tests
#### 1) Direct Attribution - De Jure and De Facto State Organs
As a general rule, a “State is responsible only for its own conduct, that is to say the conduct of persons acting, on whatever basis, on its behalf[.]”10 This includes acts:
carried out by [State] official organs, and also by persons or entities which are not formally recognized as official organs under internal law but which must nevertheless be equated with State organs because they are in a relationship of complete dependence on the State.11
These types of individuals and groups are commonly referred to as de jure and de facto State organs. Both are recognized under Articles 4-6 of the Articles on State Responsibility,12 and it is widely accepted that the conduct of de jure and de facto State organs are generally attributable to the State.13
#### 2) Imputed Attribution - Control and Direction
The conduct of a non-State actor that is neither a de jure nor de facto State organ may also be attributable to the State
“if the [non-State actor] is in fact acting on the instructions of, or under the direction or control of, [the] State in carrying out the conduct[.]”14 This direction and control test, known as the “effective control” test, reflects the lex generalis as it pertains to imputed State responsibility for the conduct of non-State actors.
##### a) Effective Control Test - Background
The “effective control” test was first outlined by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in its 1986 case concerning Military and Paramilitary Activities in and against Nicaragua wherein the Court examined whether US control over Nicaraguan Contras was sufficient to impute the actions of the Contras to the US under international law. The Court made clear that the actions of non-State actors not totally dependent on the State (but who are nonetheless paid, financed and equipped by the State) would be attributed to the State only if it were established that the State “directed or enforced the perpetration” of the internationally wrongful acts in question.15 Under this “effective control” test, the Court determined that although the US was responsible for the general “planning, direction and support” given to the Contras, the US was not internationally responsible for the internationally wrongful actions of the Contras because “there [was] no clear evidence of the US having actually exercised such a degree of control in all fields as to justify treating the [Contras] as acting on its behalf.”16 This “effective control” test, reflected in Article 8 of the Articles on State Responsibility,17 was expressly endorsed by the International Group of Experts (IGE) in the recently published Tallinn Manual 2.0 as reflective of customary international law.18
##### b) Overall Control Test Introduced
Thirteen years later, in 1999, a competing test known as the “overall control” test was introduced by the Appeals Chamber of the United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTY) in its influential Tadić opinion. The tribunal rejected the “effective control” test, and instead applied an “overall control” test to determine the attribution of acts of hierarchically structured groups, such as a military unit or armed bands of irregulars or rebels under the jus in bello.19 In such circumstances, the tribunal noted, the State will be internationally responsible for the wrongful

## c) Effective Control Test Revisited
The ICJ revisited the “effective control” test in 2007 in the case concerning the Application of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. The Court criticized the ICTY’s “overall control” test as going beyond the ICTY’s jurisdiction, and being unsupported in State practice. The Court reaffirmed the customary status of the “effective control” test, and announced that the actions of the Republika Srpska and certain paramilitary groups known as the Scorpions, Red Berets, Tigers and White Eagles were not attributable to the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) because there was insufficient evidence demonstrating that State instruction and direction was given with regard to each operation in which the alleged violations occurred, and not generally in respect of the overall actions taken by the persons or groups of persons having committed the violations.²³ Consequently, and controversially, the Court determined that the FRY could not be internationally responsible for the acts committed by the non-State actors in question, most notably for the massacres at Srebrenica.²⁴

## f) Tallinn Manual Recognition
The authors of the Tallinn Manual have also concluded that the “effective control” test is the *lex generalis* controlling imputed State responsibility for the conduct of non-State actors. The IGE recognized the tension between the “effective” and “overall” control tests in the 2013 Tallinn Manual when examining the *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello*,⁴⁰ but concluded the application of the “effective control” test in the context of peacetime operations in the revised 2017 Tallinn Manual 2.0.⁴¹ Specifically, Rule 17 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, reflecting Article 8 of the Articles on State Responsibility, provides that cyber operations conducted by a non-State actor are attributable to a State when “engaged in pursuant to its instruction or under its direction or control[.].”⁴²
By this standard, the IGE notes that a State may, either by specific direction or by exercising control over a group, in effect assume responsibility for their conduct, with each case dependent on its own facts.⁴³ Instruction within this context “refers most typically to situations in which a non-State actor functions as a State’s auxiliary.”⁴⁴ And a State is in “effective control” of a particular cyber operation by a non-State actor whenever it is the State that “determines the execution and course of the specific operation and the cyber activity engaged in by the non-State actor is an ‘integral part of that operation.’ Effective control includes both the ability to cause constituent activities of the operation to occur, as well as the ability to order the cessation of those that are underway.”⁴⁵
## III. THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CONTROL AND CAPABILITIES TEST
It is thus well accepted that the “effective control” test represents the *lex generalis* governing the attribution of internationally wrongful conduct of non-State actors to the State. As the *lex generalis*, this test applies in all situations unless there is an express *lex specialis* providing otherwise.⁴⁶

This state practice involves States that have publicly attributed the cyber operations of non-State actors to States on the basis the basis of a multitude of factors, including but not limited to (1) the relationship between the non-State actor and the State, if any; (2) the cyber methods used by the non-State actor and whether those methods are similar to the State; (3) the motivations of the two parties, if known; (4) the similarity in technology and/or code used by the two parties; (5) the technical capabilities of the two parties; and (6) geographic location. Direction and control have not been dispositive factors. a) US Attribution - DNC / US Election In June 2016, the private security firm CrowdStrike issued a report entitled “Bears in the Midst: Intrusion into the Democratic National Committee.”77 In the report, Crowdstrike described an investigation into the 2015 and 2016 cyber breaches of the Democratic National Committee’s (DNC) computer systems,78 and identified two “sophisticated adversaries on the network - COZY BEAR and FANCY BEAR.”79 CrowdStrike concluded these two adversaries were linked to the Russian State because of their “advanced methods consistent with nation-state level capabilities including deliberate targeting and ‘access management’ tradecraft[,]” and because both adversaries “engage in extensive political and economic espionage for the benefit of the government of the Russian Federation and are believed to be closely linked to the Russian government’s powerful and highly capable intelligence services”.80 CrowdStrike determined that COZY BEAR had infiltrated the DNC’s computer systems in the summer of 2015, and FANCY BEAR had breached the network in April 2016.81 In October 2016, the US Director of National Intelligence (DNI) issued a joint statement on behalf of the DNI and the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) stating that the US Intelligence Community was “confident” that the “Russian Government directed the recent compromises of e-mails from US persons and institutions, including from US political organizations.”82 The evidence to support this conclusion, however, was that the subsequent disclosures of “hacked e-mails” that followed the DNC intrusion were “consistent with the methods and motivations of Russian-directed efforts[.]”83 Specifically, the DNI and DHS stated that such thefts and disclosures are reflective of past Russian efforts “across Europe and Eurasia” to “influence public opinion there.”84 Based on the “scope and sensitivity of these efforts,” the DNI and DHS concluded that “only Russia’s senior-most officials could have authorized these activities.”85 Several months later, in January 2017, the DHS and the FBI issued a Joint Analysis Report entitled “GRIZZLY STEPPE - Russian Malicious Cyber Activity.” In the report, the DHS and FBI expanded on the October 2016 Joint Statement issued by the DNI and DHS, and publicly attributed the DNC cyber intrusion to the Russian State based on a series of “technical indicators”: Previous JARs have not attributed malicious cyber activity to specific countries or threat actors. However, public attribution of these activities to [Russian civilian and military intelligence Services] is supported by technical indicators from the U.S. Intelligence Community, DHS, FBI, the private sector, and other entities.86 According to the Joint Report, those “technical indicators” prove the threat actors are “likely associated” with the Russian State.87 The Joint Report was widely panned by industry experts for its purported failure to provide a “smoking gun” that showed Russian control or direction over the DNC intrusion, and for using false technical indicators linking the purported threat actors to the Russian State.88 But the focus of the Joint Report was not on express direction or control. It instead focused on capabilities, methods, motivations and technical indicators, reflecting the development of the control and capabilities test as the growing lex specialis for imputed State attribution for the unlawful cyber operations of non-State actors.
b) US Attribution - Yahoo Breach In March 2017, the US DOJ announced the indictments of five individuals, including two Russian officials, for “computer hacking, economic espionage and other criminal offenses in connection with a conspiracy, beginning in January 2014, to access Yahoo’s network and the contents of webmail accounts."89 In the indictment, the DOJ alleged that"officers of the Russian Federal Security Service"and"intelligence and law enforcement agency of the Russian Federation""conspired together and with each other to protect, direct, facilitate, and pay criminal hackers to collect information through computer intrusions in the United States and elsewhere."90 The evidence cited to link the Russian officials to the"criminal hackers", however, was less than express direction and control: (1) the criminal hackers obtained evidence of"information of predictable interest to the FSB", including access to"Russian journalists and politicians critical of the Russian government"(i.e., motivations); (2) the geographic location of the criminal hackers; (3) the ability of the Russian State to"arrest and prosecute"the criminal hackers and its failure to do so; and (4) threadbare allegations that the Russian officials provided direction to the criminal hackers.91 The focus therefore was on motivations, capabilities and geographic proximity, in combination with conclusory allegations of State direction. The test applied was not the"effective control"test. The DOJ focused on control and capabilities.
## c) Ukraine Attribution - NotPetya Ransomware In June 2017, a particularly devastating strain of ransomware began infecting PC's around the world.92 The"blast radius"of the attack was in Ukraine, where 60% of the infected machines were located.93 Other infected machines belonged to international companies that operate within Ukraine.94 A group called"GoldenEye"claimed responsibility for the attack.95 Ukraine's state security service, the SBU, publicly attributed the attack to the Russian State based on: (1) similar motivations between the suspected hackers and the Russian State; and (2) similar code used by the suspected hackers and other hackers Ukraine suspects are connected to the Russian State.96 The attribution was"largely based on similarities in tools and techniques"rather"than any obvious, direct correlation."97 ## 5) Situations To Watch ### a) French Election Just prior to the most recent French presidential election, a number of sensitive e-mails from the Macron campaign were disclosed online. The United States warned French authorities that Russian-based hackers were targeting France's computer infrastructure in the run-up to the presidential election, a"revelation likely to intensify speculation that Moscow was responsible for dumping a huge trove of hacked documents days before the election."98 One former intelligence official told Foreign Policy that the evidence relied upon by the United States may be"signatures"used by Russian hacking groups, such as"pieces of malicious code or the use of a particular server."99 Sources also point to the motivations of the purported bad actors, a common factor in the control and capabilities test. Whether the French State takes a similar approach that the US took in attributing the 2016 election interference to Russia based on"technical indicators"remains to be seen.
### b) WannaCry Ransomware Attack In May 2017, hundreds of thousands of computers were hijacked by a virus called"WannaCry."100 The WannaCry virus acted as a ransomware, freezing computer files and demanding a ransom for their release. WannaCry impacted approximately 150 countries over the course of a weekend, and shut down hospitals in the United Kingdom.101 Analysts quickly noticed that a few lines of code used in the attack appeared in the hacking tools commonly used by the"Lazarus https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomasbrewster/2017/07/03/russia-suspect-in-ransomware-attacks-says-ukraine/#38e27e376b89.

group,” the same group that the US blamed for the 2014 Sony attack.¹⁰² Whether States adopt this attribution analysis by private security firms, based on the same standard adopted by the US in 2014, will help determine if the control and capabilities test is, in fact, a developing *lex specialis*.
c) APT 32 Researches at cybersecurity company FireEye have identified an espionage group “aligned with Vietnamese state interests” as the “perpetrators of cyberattacks dating back as far as 2013[.]”¹⁰³ This new report bases its loose attribution on the fact that APT32 has an interest in political influence and foreign governments, targets the private sector with ties to Vietnam, and has tactics that makes clear that APT32 operators are “well-resourced and supported as they use a large set of domains and IP addresses as command and control infrastructure.”¹⁰⁴ IV. IMPACT OF TEST The impact of the development State practice applying the control and capabilities test remains to be seen. There are, however, some demonstrable benefits and drawbacks to the control and capabilities approach. One benefit is easier attribution. By using the control and capabilities standard, as opposed to the effective control standard, offended States will have quicker recourse to attribution, and therefore quicker recourse to a lawful response. This benefit is also a downside. Quicker attribution can also lead to false positives. It is widely known within the cyber community that States can mask their true identity, and make it appear that the attack is originating in a separate State. This capability was recently disclosed in a set of Wikileaks disclosures called “Vault 7.”
It’s also unclear whether the State practice described above is being carried out with a sense of legal obligation, or political expediency. One drawback to the development of this test, and to attribution tests in cyberspace generally, has been the private nature in which States go about their research and attribution analysis. Without public statements of attribution, tied with statements of legal certainty, it will be difficult to have a conclusive determination as to whether the control and capabilities test has reached the level of customary international law.
That said, the effective control test is outdated as compared to the technological advances in cyberspace. States need to adopt a new standard in order to adapt with the tools available to States.
V. CONCLUSION The foregoing examples of State practice support the conclusion that imputed State responsibility for the unlawful cyber operations of non-State actors who are neither *de jure* nor *de facto* State organs is being assigned without rigid adherence to the “effective control” test. Again, this is just State practice demonstrating at least one element of determining State responsibility. State attribution under the new model is being assigned based on a control and capabilities test, examining motivations, geographic location, technical indicators, and relationship between the non-State actor and the State.
These State examples, of course, are not conclusive. This paper does not argue that such limited examples of State practice, alone, constitute a binding principle of customary international law. This State practice does, however, indicate that a *lex specialis* is forming that, if risen to the level of customary international law, would supplant the *lex generalis* “effective control” test, endorsed in Article 8 of the Articles on State Responsibility and Rule 17 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0. Such a change would radically alter the attribution models available in cyberspace.
